text.0: with this my song i strive to reach this guest of yours who wakes at early morn the lord of all the tribes.
text.1: each time he comes from heaven the pure one from of old from ancient days the child cats everlasting food.
text.2: whom welldis sed the blirgus stablished as a rriend whom men must glorify highflaming in the wood.
text.3: as such most friendly thou art every day extolled in lauds by vitahavya o thou wondrous god.
text.4: be thou the foeless helper of the skilful man subduer of the enemy near or far away.
text.5: bestow a wealthy home on men o son of strength give vitahavya riches spreading far and wide give bharadvāja widespread wealth.
text.6: him your refulgent guest agni who comes from heaven the herald of mankind wellskilled in sacred rites.
text.7: who like a holy singer utters heavenly words oblationbearer envoy god i seek with hymns.
text.8: who with his purifying eyeattracting form hath shone upon the earth as with the light of dawn.
text.9: who speeding on as in the fight of etaia cometh untouched by age as one athirst in heat.
text.10: worship ye agni agni with your log of wood praise your beloved your beloved guest with songs.
text.11: invite ye the immortal hither with your hymns a god among the gods he loveth what is choice loveth our service god mid gods.
text.12: agni inflamed with fuel in my song i sing pure cleanser steadlast set in tront at sacrifice.
text.13: wise jātavedas we implore with prayers for bliss the priest the holy singer bounteous void of guile.
text.14: men agni in each age have made thee deathiess one their envoy offeringbearer guard adorable.
text.15: with reverence gods and mortals have established thee the everwatchful omnipresent household lord.
text.16: thou agni ordering the works and ways of both as envoy of the gods traversest both the worlds.
text.17: when we lay claim to thy regard and gracious fare be thou to us a thriceprotecting friendly guard.
text.18: him fair of face rapid and fair to look on him very wise may we who know not follow.
text.19: let him who knows all rules invite for worship agru announce our offering to the immortals.
text.20: him agni thou deliverest and savest who brings him prayer to thee the wise o hero.
text.21: the end of sacrifice or its inception yea thou endowest him with power and riches.
text.22: guard us from him who would assail us agni preserve us o thou victor from dishonour.
text.23: here let the place of darkening come upon thee may wealth be ours desirable in thousands.
text.24: agni the priest is king lord of the homestead he jatayedas knows all generations.
text.25: most skilful worshipper mid gods and mortals may he begin the sacrifice the holy.
text.26: whateer today thou brightflamed priest enjoyest from the mans ritefor thou art sacrificer.
text.27: worship for duly dost thou spread in greatness bear off thine ofrerings of today most youthful.
text.28: look thou upon the viands duly laid for thee fain would he set thee here to worship heaven andearth.
text.29: help us o liberal agni in the strife for spoil so that we may oercome all things that trouble us oercome oercome them with thy help.
text.30: together with all gods o fairfaced agni be seated first upon the woollined altar.
text.31: nestlike bedewed with oil bear this our worship to savitar who sacrifices rightly.
text.32: here the arranging priests as did atharvan rub this agni forth.
text.33: whom not bewildered as he moved in winding ways they brought from gloom.
text.34: for the gods banquet be thou born for full perfection and for weal.
text.35: bring the immortal gods who strengthen holy law so let our sacrifice reach the gods.
text.36: o agni lord and master of mens homesteads with kindled fuel we have made thee mighty.
text.37: let not our household gear be found defective sharpen us with thy penetrating splendour.
